channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: The Red Chains of Bureaucracy That ‘Torment’ Chinese
item.description: A politician in the southern city of Guangzhou has listed more than 100 documents the average citizen needs in a lifetime, arguing that China’s bureaucracy is too tortuous. His proposal for streamlining has been met with approval.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:credit: Credit: Courtesy of the Nanfang Daily
item.media:description: Cao Zhiwei displays a scroll showing the 103 documents an average Chinese needs over the course of his life, at a meeting in Guangzhou of the local committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Billionaire’s Arrest Intensifies Focus on Former Security Chief
item.description: Liu Han is one of several tycoons arrested in the southwestern province of Sichuan in the past year, in a crackdown on corruption that has netted several former associates of China’s former head of internal security, Zhou Yongkang.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: Liu Han, a mining tycoon accused of running a "mafia-style gang," in 2008. His arrest last year had international implications.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: 2 Prominent Women Under Detention Are Hospitalized
item.description: Lawyers and friends of Liu Xia and Cao Shunli said long-term detention had damaged their health.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Kontea Journal: Greek and Turkish Cypriots Unite to Restore a Church and a Bond
item.description: The people of Cyprus have started to do what their political leaders have been unable to accomplish: reconcile after the island was partitioned in 1974.
item.dc:creator: By LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:credit: Angelos Tzortzinis for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mosque stands near the church of St. Charalambos, in Kontea, in the Turkish-controlled north of Cyprus. The church had fallen into disrepair since the island nation was divided in 1974.

item.title: Militants Attack Presidential Palace in Somalia
item.description: President Hassan Sheik Mohamud was unhurt, according to diplomats in the capital, Mogadishu, after explosions and gunfire rocked the compound.
item.dc:creator: By MOHAMMED IBRAHIM and NICHOLAS KULISH

item.title: Libyan Military Plane Crash in Tunisia Kills 11
item.description: An Islamist official in Libya's government and 10 other passengers and crew were killed when a military plane carrying medical patients crashed near Tunisia's capital early on Friday, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: India Ink: Snapdeal, the EBay of India, Sees Plenty of Room to Grow
item.description: The e-commerce company has been called the eBay of India, but its chief executive has been drawing parallels to the Chinese juggernaut Alibaba.
item.dc:creator: By MARK BERGEN
item.media:description: Kunal Bahl, chief executive of Snapdeal, one of India's largest online marketplace.

item.title: South Korea Gives Aid to North Amid Family Reunions
item.description: The shipment of medicine and powdered milk to North Korea was seen as another sign of thawing relations between the two countries.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Ukraine Announces Tentative Accord to End Crisis
item.description: After days of bloodshed in the capital, President Viktor F. Yanukovych said he would call new elections and reduce presidential powers.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER and ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:description: Antigovernment protesters man a barricade in Kiev on Friday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Obama’s Plan to Meet Dalai Lama Draws Swift Chinese Rebuke
item.description: The meeting is likely to anger the Chinese government, which has tried to diminish the influence of the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader and his efforts to promote the autonomy of Tibet.
item.category: American Enterprise Institute for Public Policy Research
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY
item.media:description: An audience member at the American Enterprise Institute took a picture of himself with the Dalai Lama on Thursday in Washington.

item.title: Ukraine’s Forces Escalate Attacks Against Protesters
item.description: New violence in Kiev left the country reeling from the biggest one-day death toll since Ukrainian independence from the Soviet Union.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER and ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: World Briefing: Iraq: Mortar Fire Kills at Least 21 People
item.description: Seven mortar shells fell on the Shiite town of Musayyib, south of Baghdad, on Thursday, killing 21 people and wounding 65, Iraqi officials said.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Islamic State of Iraq and Syria
item.dc:creator: By DURAID ADNAN

item.title: In Ukraine’s West, a Jumping-Off Point for Volunteers Heading to Kiev
item.description: Lviv is the recruiting center for volunteers to staff the bloodied protest ramparts in the capital, 330 miles to the east.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.media:description: Women in Lviv, Ukraine,organized bus rides for protesters to Kiev, the capital, on Thursday. Six hundred people a day are signing up to go to Kiev.

item.title: World Briefing: China: Dissident’s Wife Is Hospitalized
item.description: Liu Xia, the wife of Liu Xiaobo, the imprisoned dissident who won the 2010 Nobel Peace Prize, has been hospitalized, according to family friends.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: World Briefing: Britain: Defense Heard in Hacking Case
item.description: Rebekah Brooks, the former chief executive of Rupert Murdoch’s British newspaper unit, testified in court on Thursday that she did not know about the activities of a private investigator who has admitted that he hacked phones on behalf of The News of the World.
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: World Briefing: India: Court Blocks Prisoners’ Release
item.description: The Supreme Court ruled Thursday that the Tamil Nadu state government could not immediately release three of the seven prisoners serving life sentences for the assassination of Rajiv Gandhi, a lawyer for the state government said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Governor of Nigeria’s Central Bank Is Fired After Warning of Missing Oil Revenue
item.description: President Goodluck Jonathan’s dismissal of Lamido Sanusi, who had charged that billions in oil revenue was missing, was seen as a lack of resolve in tackling corruption.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:description: Lamido Sanusi was dismissed on Thursday after charging the national oil company with failing to turn over billions of dollars.

item.title: World Briefing: Greece: Far-Rightists’ Immunity at Risk
item.description: Judges handling a criminal investigation into the country’s far-right party Golden Dawn asked Parliament on Thursday to permit the prosecution of nine more of the party’s 18 lawmakers.
item.dc:creator: By NIKI KITSANTONIS

item.title: Dead Guards on Freighter Are Identified as Former Navy SEAL Members
item.description: The two men, who had been hired to protect a ship that was attacked by Somali pirates in 2009, were found dead while the ship was docked in the Seychelles.
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH and MARK MAZZETTI

item.title: Libyan Vote on Charter Assembly Is Marred by Violence and Low Turnout
item.description: Efforts to draft a new Constitution in Libya hit another hurdle when elections for a 60-member drafting committee fell short of expectations.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: A Chinese Spy Novelist’s World of Dark Secrets
item.description: Mai Jia, who once worked for the Chinese military in the secretive world of cryptography, is a top-selling novelist. His first novel to appear in English, “Decoded,” is about to be published.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mai Jia, one of China's most successful authors, says that paradise for him is a secluded library.

item.title: Protests Swell in Venezuela as Places to Rally Disappear
item.description: As Venezuelans take to the streets to condemn perennial problems like crime and shortages, the intensity of the protests is fueled by a sense that the spaces to demonstrate are shrinking.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: Banging pots in protest in Caracas as Leopoldo López, an opposition politician, passed by in a car after surrendering.

item.title: Converts Join With Militants in Kiev Clash
item.description: Groups of young men with far-right political affiliations in Ukraine have provided much of the front-line muscle in increasingly bloody clashes with the police.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS and ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters extended barricades at Independence Square in Kiev, the Ukrainian capital, on Thursday.

item.title: Egypt Extends Its Crackdown to Journalists
item.description: The military government has been detaining reporters, as well as other perceived enemies like activists and Islamists.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: Reporters and relatives of three Al Jazeera English journalists waited at Tora prison in Cairo.

item.title: Haitian Dictator May Be Charged With Human Rights Crimes, Court Says
item.description: An appeals court rejected an argument from Jean-Claude Duvalier, known as Baby Doc, that the statute of limitations had expired for the charge of crimes against humanity.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD
